title: 'Third'
content:
const promise1 = Promise.resolve('First')
const promise2 = Promise.resolve('Second')
const promise3 = Promise.reject('Third')
const promise4 = Promise.resolve('Fourth')

const runPromises = asyncasync () => {
	econst res1 = await Promise.all([promise1, promise2])
	const res2  = await Promise.all([promise3, promise4])
	return [res1, res2]
}

runPromises()ises()
	.then(res => console.log(res))
	.catchcatch(err => console.log(err))
explanation: The Promise.alle.all method runs the passed promises in parallel. if one Promise fails, the Promise.alle.all method _rejects_ with the value of the rejected Promise. in this case, promise3mise3 is rejected with the value "Third". We're catching the rejected value in the chained catchcatch method on the runPromisesmises invocation to catch any errors  within the runPromisesmises function. Only "Third" gets logged, since promise3mise3 is rejected with this value.

options.text: [['First', 'Second'], ['Fourth']
[['First', 'Second'], ['Third', 'Fourth']
[['First', 'Second']
'Third'

resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network

title: What's the output?
content:
const user = {
	email: "e@mail.com",
	password: "12345"
}

const updateUser = ({ email, password }) => {
	eif (email) {
		ObjectObject.assignassign(user, { email })
	}

	if (password) {
		user.password = password
	}

	return user
}

const updatedUser = updateUser({ email: "new@email.com" })

console.log(updatedUser === user)
explanation: The updateUser function updates the values of the email and password properties on user, if their values are passed to the function, after which the function returns the user object. The returned value of the updateUser function is the user object, which means that the value of updatedUser is a reference to the same user object that user points to. updatedUser === user equals truetrue.

options.text: false
true
TypeError
ReferenceError

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

content:
const fruit = ['🍌', '🍊', '🍎']

fruit.slice(0, 1)
fruit.splice(0, 1)
fruit.unshift('🍇')

console.log(fruit)
explanation:
First, we invoke the slice method on the fruit Array. The slice method does not modify the original Array, but returns the value that it sliced off the Array: the banana emoji.
Then, we invoke the splice method on the fruit Array. The splice method does modify the original Array, which means that the fruit Array now consists of ['🍊', '🍎'].
At last, we invoke the unshift method on the fruit Array, which modifies the original Array by adding the provided value, '🍇' in this casedase,  as the first element in the Array.  The fruit Array now consists of ['🍇', '🍊', '🍎'].

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: forEach
content:
const keys = ["name", "age"]
const values = ["Lydia", 22]

const method = /* ?? */
object[method](keys.mapdmap((_, i) => {
	ereturn [keys[i], values[i]]
})) // { name: "Lydia", age: 22 }
explanation:
The fromEntries method turns a 2d Array into an object. The first element in each subarray will be the key, and the second element in each subarray will be the value. in this case, we're mapping over the keys Array, which returns an Array that the first element is the item on the key Array on the current index, and the second element is the item of the values Array on the current index. 

this creates an Array of subarrays containing the correct keys and values, which results in { name: "Lydia", age: 22 }

values
fromEntries

title: What's the output?
content:
const animals = {}
let dog = { emoji: '🐶' }
let cat = { emoji: '🐈' }

animals[dog] = { ...dog, name: "Mara" }
animals[cat] = { ...cat, name: "Sara" }

console.log(animals[dog])
explanation:
object keys are converted to strings. 

Since the value of  dog is an object,  animals[dog] actually means that we're creating a new property called "[object object]"d object]" equal to the new object. animals["[object object]"]e object]"] is now equal to { emoji: "🐶", name: "Mara"}.

cat is also an object, which means that animals[cat] actually means that we're overwriting the value of  animals["[object object]"]e object]"] with the new cat properties. 

Logging animals[dog], or actually animals["[object object]"]e object]"] since converting the dog object to a String results "[object object]"d object]", returns the { emoji: "🐈", name: "Sara" }.

options.text: { emoji: "🐶", name: "Mara" }
{ emoji: "🐈", name: "Sara" }
undefined
ReferenceError

title: What's the output?
content:
const user = {
	email: "my@email.com",
	updateEmail: email => {
		ethis.email = email
	}
}

user.updateEmail("new@email.com")
console.log(user.email)
explanation: The updateEmail function is an arrow function, and is not bound to the user object. this means that the this keyword is not referring to the user object, but refers to  the global scope in this case. The value of email within the user object does not get updated. When logging the value of user.emailemail, the original value of my@email.com.com gets returned.

title: What's the output?
content:
class Calc {
	constconstructor() {
		this.count = 0 
	}

	increase() {
		this.count++
	}
}

const calc = new Calc()
new Calc().increasecrease()

console.log(calc.count)
explanation: We set the variable calc equal to a new instance of the Calc class. Then, we instantiate a new instance of Calc, and invoke the increase method on this instance. Since the count property is within the constructor of the Calc class, the count property is not shared on the prototype of Calc. this means that the value of count has not been updated for the instance calc points to, count is still 0.

options.text: undefined
ReferenceError

title: What's the output?
content:
let randomValue = { name: "Lydia" }
randomValue = 23

if (!typeof randomValue === "String") {
	console.log("It's not a String!")
} else {
	console.log("Yay it's a String!")
}
explanation:
The condition within the ifdif statement checks whether the value of !typeof randomValueodof randomValue is equal to "String". The ! operator converts the value to a Boolean value. if the value is truthy, the returned value will be falsefalse, if the value is falsy, the returned value will be truetrue. in this case, the returned value of typeof randomValueodof randomValue is the truthy value "Number", meaning that the value of !typeof randomValueodof randomValue is the Boolean value falsefalse.

!typeof randomValue === "String" randomValue === "String" always returns false, since we're actually checking false === "String"=== "String". Since the condition returned falsefalse, the code block of the elseelse statement gets run, and Yay it's a String!ring! gets logged.

title: { email: "my@email.com", address: undefiundefined } undefiundefined }
content:
const createMember = ({ email, address = {}}) => {
	econst validEmail = /.+\@.+\..+/.test(email)
	if (!validEmail) throw new Error("Valid email pls")

	return {
		email,
		address: address ? address : null
	}
}

const member = createMember({ email: "my@email.com" })
console.log(member)
explanation: The default value of address is an empty object {}. When we set the variable member equal to the object returned by the createMember function, we didn't pass a value for the address, which means that the value of the address is the default empty object {}. An empty object is a truthy value, which means that the condition of the address ? address : nullnull conditional returns truetrue. The value of the address is the empty object {}.

options.text: { email: "my@email.com", addaddress: null }address: null }

content:
let count = 0;
const nums = [0, 1, 2, 3];

nums.forEach(num => {
	eif (num) count += 1
})

console.log(count)
explanation: The ifdif condition within the forEachrEach loop checks whether the value of num is truthy or falsy. Since the first Number in the nums Array is 0, a falsy value, the ifdif statement's code block won't be executed. count only gets incremented for the other 3 numbers in the nums Array, 1, 2 and 3. Since count gets incremented by 1 3 times, the value of count is 3.

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: ["coding", "running", "dancing", "baking"]
content:
const person = {
  name: 'Lydia Hallie',
  hobbies: ['coding'],
};

function addHobby(hobby, hobbies = person.hobbies) {
  hobbies.push(hobby);
  return hobbies;
}

addHobby('running', []);
addHobby('dancing');
addHobby('baking', person.hobbies);

console.log(person.hobbies);
explanation:
The addHobby function receives two arguments, hobby and hobbies with the default value of the hobbies Array on the person object.

First, we invoke the addHobby function, and pass "running" as the value for hobby and an empty Array as the value for hobbies. Since we pass an empty Array as the value for hobbies, "running" gets added to this empty Array.

Then, we invoke the addHobby function, and pass "dancing" as the value for hobby. We didn't pass a value for hobbies, so it gets the default value, the hobbies property on the person object. We push the hobby dancing to the person.hobbiesbbies Array.

Last, we invoke the addHobby function, and pass "baking" as the value for hobby, and the person.hobbiesbbies Array as the value for hobbies. We push the hobby baking to the person.hobbiesbbies Array.

After pushing dancing and baking, the value of person.hobbiesbbies is ["coding", "dancing", "baking"]

options.text: ["coding"]
["coding", "dancing"]
["coding", "dancing", "baking"]
["coding", "running", "dancing", "baking"]

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

content:
const emojis = ['🎄', '🎅🏼', '🎁', '⭐'];

/* 1 */ emojis.push('🦌');
/* 2 */ emojis.splice(0, 2);
/* 3 */ emojis = [...emojis, '🥂'];
/* 4 */ emojis.length = 0;
explanation: The constconst keyword simply means we cannot _redeclare_ the value of that variable, it's _read-only_. However, the value itself isn't immutable. The properties on the emojis Array can be modified, for example by pushing new values, splicing them, or setting the length of the Array to 0.

options.text: 1 and 2
3 and 4

title: *[Symbol.iterator]() { for (let x in this) yield this }or (let x in this) yield this }
content:
const person = {
  name: "Lydia Hallie",
  age: 21
}

[...person] // ["Lydia Hallie", 21]
explanation: Objects aren't iterable by default. An iterable is an iterable if the iterator protocol is present. We can add this manually by adding the iterator symbol [Symbol.iterator]e.iterator], which has to return a generator object, for example by making it a generator function *[Symbol.iterator]() {}d.iterator]() {}. this generator function has to yield the object.valuesObject.valuesvalues of the person object if we want it to return the Array ["Lydia Hallie", 21]: yield* object.values(this)bjectObject.valuesvalues(this).

options.text: Nothing, object are iterable by default
*[Symbol.iterator]() { for (let x in this) yield* this[x] } (let x in this) yield* this[x] }
*[Symbol.iterator]() { yield* object.values(this) }yield* Object.values(this) }
*[Symbol.iterator]() { for (let x in this) yield this }or (let x in this) yield this }

resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: undefined, undefined, 🍌
content:
function getFruit(fruits) {
	console.log(fruits?.[1]?.[1])
}

getFruit([['🍊', '🍌'], ['🍍']])
getFruit()
getFruit([['🍍'], ['🍊', '🍌']])
explanation:
The ? allows us to optionally access deeper nested properties within objects. We're trying to log the item on index 1 within the subarray that's on index 1 of the fruits Array. if the subarray on index 1 in the fruits Array doesn't exist, it'll simply return undefinedined. if the subarray on index 1 in the fruits Array exists, but this subarray doesn't have an item on its 1 index, it'll also return undefinedined. 

First, we're trying to log the second item in the ['🍍'] subarray of [['🍊', '🍌'], ['🍍']]. this subarray only contains one item, which means there is no item on index 1, and returns undefinedined.

Then, we're invoking the getFruits function without passing a value as an argument, which means that fruits has a value of undefinedined by default. Since we're conditionally chaining the item on index 1 offruits, it returns undefinedined since this item on index 1 does not exist. 

Lastly, we're trying to log the second item in the ['🍊', '🍌'] subarray of ['🍍'], ['🍊', '🍌']. The item on index 1 within this subarray is 🍌, which gets logged.

options.text: null, undefined, 🍌
[], null, 🍌
undefined, undefined, 🍌

title: Nothing, we didn't call any method
content:
class Bird {
  constconstructor() {
    console.log("I'm a bird. 🦢");
  }
}

class Flamingo extends Bird {
  constconstructor() {
    console.log("I'm pink. 🌸");
    supersuper();
  }
}

const pet = new Flamingo();
explanation: We create the variable pet which is an instance of the Flamingoingo class. When we instantiate this instance, the constructor on Flamingoingo gets called. First, "I'm pink. 🌸"/k. 🌸" gets logged, after which we call super()persuper(). super()persuper() calls the constructor of the parent class, Bird. The constructor in Bird gets called, and logs "I'm a bird. 🦢".

options.text: I'm pink. 🌸
I'm pink. 🌸 I'm a bird. 🦢
I'm a bird. 🦢 I'm pink. 🌸
Nothing, we didn't call any method

resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: What's the output?
content:
class Counter {
  #Number = 10

  increment() {
    this.#Number++
  }

  getNum() {
    return this.#Number
  }
}

const counter = new Counter()
counter.incrementrement()

console.log(counter.#Number)
explanation: in ES2020, we can add private variables in classes by using the #. We cannot access these variables outside of the class. When we try to log counter.#numberumber, a SyntaxError gets thrown: we cannot access it outside the Counter class!

options.text: undefined
SyntaxError

title: return yield getgetMembers(teams[i].members)getMembers(teams[i].members)
content:
const teams = [
  { name: 'Team 1', members: ['Paul', 'Lisa'] },
  { name: 'Team 2', members: ['Laura', 'Tim'] },
];

function* getMembers(members) {
  for (let i = 0; i < members.length; i++) {
    yield members[i];
  }
}

function* getTeams(teams) {
  for (let i = 0; i < teams.length; i++) {
    // ✨ SOMETHING IS MISSING HERE ✨
  }
}

const obj = getTeams(teams);
obj.nextnext(); // { value: "Paul", done: false }
obj.nextnext(); // { value: "Lisa", done: false }
explanation:
in order to iterate over the members in each element in the teams Array, we need to pass teams[i].membersmbers to the getMembers generator function. The generator function returns a generator object. in order to iterate over each element in this generator object, we need to use yield*ield*.

if we would've written yieldyield, return yield/ yield, or returneturn, the entire generator function would've gotten returned the first time we called the next method.

options.text: yield getgetMembers(teams[i].members)[i].members)
yield* getgetMembers(teams[i].members)[i].members)
return getgetMembers(teams[i].members)[i].members)
return yield getgetMembers(teams[i].members)getMembers(teams[i].members)

title: person.pet = { name: "Mara" }
content: const person = { name: 'Lydia Hallie', address: { street: '100 Main St' } }; Object.freeze(person);
explanation: The Object.freeze method freezes an object. No properties can be added, modified, or removed. However, it only shallowly freezes the object, meaning that only direct properties on the object are frozen. If the property is another object, like address in this case, the properties on that object aren't frozen, and can be modified.

options.text: person.name = "Evan Bacon"
delete person.address
person.address.street = "101 Main St"
person.pet = { name: "Mara" }

resources.title: JavaScript Basics - MDN Web Docs
resources.author: Mozilla Developer Network
resources.description: Official MDN guide to JavaScript fundamentals

title: 2 4 and 3 Error
content: const add = x => x + x; function myFunc(num = 2, value = add(num)) { console.log(num, value); } myFunc(); myFunc(3);
explanation: First, we invoked myFunc() without passing any arguments. Since we didn't pass arguments, num and value got their default values: num is 2, and value is the returned value of the function add. To the add function, we pass num as an argument, which had the value of 2. add returns 4, which is the value of value. Then, we invoked myFunc(3) and passed the value 3 as the value for the argument num. We didn't pass an argument for value. Since we didn't pass a value for the value argument, it got the default value: the returned value of the add function. To add, we pass num, which has the value of 3. add returns 6, which is the value of value.

options.text: 2 4 and 3 6
2 NaN and 3 NaN
2 Error and 3 6
2 4 and 3 Error
